You are a requirements analyst auditing discussion forum posts for potential feature requests.
You will be provided with a Moodle discussion forum post that includes the post title and post description. Moodle is a free and open-source learning management system (LMS) used by schools, universities, and workplaces to create online courses and manage learning activities.
Your task is to classify if the provided discussion forum post is a feature request or not for Moodle. A feature request is a post where the user asks for new functionality, missing functionality (e.g., features available in other apps), new content, or changes/improvements to existing features in future releases. Posts that are not feature requests include: bug reports, troubleshooting questions, usage questions, configuration issues, announcements, or general discussions. 
Respond strictly with one of the following labels: FEATURE_REQUEST or NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. If the forum post is a feature request, return FEATURE_REQUEST. If the forum post is not a feature request, return NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. Use the title of the post and the description of the post to make the assessment.
Forum Post: 
Post title: Cloud PoodLL video recorder and screen reader
Post description: One of our instructors has a student who uses a screen reader and they found that the Cloud PoodLL video recorder was not screen reader accessible. I found this earlier discussion that mentioned screen readers and PoodLL and wondered if there are any updates: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=276322 Should we expect the recorder to work with screen readers, and if so, what suggestions are there for making it work?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Less strict settings in Speechcards / Minilesson?
Post description: Hello everybody, hello Justin, We have been using Poodll, this great tool for language teaching, for four years now, and it's really fabulous. There are so many things you can do with it, especially get students of foreign languages to speak, which is not an easy task given that they are often very numerous in a university class... Wo use Read Aloud a lot, but I'm new to Minilessons, and haven't been using the widgets much either. So here's the question: in some cases, like in Minilesson or Speechcards, Poodll seems to consider my answers as incorrect how ever hard I try. In the Speechcards items I get like two stars out of three but I'm stuck there (I would love to use this to create structural exercises like Does he like it?|Yes he does - that's a great additional possibility!). I can't see any settings to configure the way it is graded, like I do in Read Aloud - would anyone know if that's possible, and how to do it? Thank you!

Post title: PoodLL in Firefox
Post description: I'm wondering if there is a known issue with Poodll in the Firefox browser. We have an assignment activity set up with PoodLL recording. Several students had no issues, but a couple of students reported that they had problems with the recorder. It's very difficult to get more information from them but one student said only the first 30 seconds of her recording were uploaded even though the recorder is set to 3 minutes. She was using Firefox. I tried the activity in Chrome with no issue but when I tried it in Firefox, only the first 15 seconds of the 1 minute recording got uploaded. I'm a bit behind on my updates but this is what we're currently using: Online Poodll Submissions 3.14 Poodll recording 3.1.05 Poodll filter 3.1.39 Moodle - latest version of 3.8

Post title: Warning -dumb question
Post description: Moodle 3.72 query This looks fabulous - but just a little worried about storage implications with 10,000 students. 1. Is the teachers marking Audio or video feedbakc hosted on the same server of offloaded elsewhere? 2. If it is on the moodle HTML server does this terrific tool allow the video or audio files to be hosted else where off server? eg free file hosting services? 3. MOST IMPORTANTLY - does this have an expiry for the feedback files to be stored - or to auto-delete after playback by the learner (I know what you're thinking "this message will self destruct" etc) but  I need to know about lifecycle management of rich media as 4 meg feedback x 10-20 feedbacks per year x 1000 (never mind) 10000 students is a concern... Any and all feedback welcome (especially if your answers follow the 1,2,3 numbering!!) Dom

Post description: Hello we have just installed a number of PoodLL plugins on our moodle development environment in hopes of replacing nanogong and have seen some weirdness. Forum Post: 
Post title: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
Post description: Hello Community; I am struggling to get consistent and good performance out of Poodll/Moodle specifically regarding mobile uploads of video assignments. I am evaluating Poodll in a self hosted virtual instance of Moodle, and have found that although small mobile video files under 10MB will generally upload via Poodll and play back without issue on the source device, once the file size exceeds roughly 15-20MB, then things start to fall apart. Background... My use case requires that all students will be submitting assignments via mobile device platforms, which if I understand correctly would be best served by converting submissions via FFMPEG for widest mobile platform compatibility. Therefore, I have built FFMPEG on my test server from sources, and have verified that when called from the system path, it is working correctly. I have also verified via shell command that the FFMPEG switches used on the poodll demo site are working. Therefore, I assume that the Poodll Filter settings to auto convert mobile submissions to MP4 and to use FFMPEG for the conversion are also working, although I have yet to determine how to verify this as I have not seen any entries in any server logs. Back to the problem at hand... Without FFMPEG settings enabled in the Poodll filter, files of any size, up to the server limit of 512MB, will upload from a mobile device without issue. Playback is choppy over mobile data, but plays smoothly via WiFi, suggesting that playback quality is bandwidth dependent. With FFMPEG conversion settings enabled in the Poodll filter, mobile uploads above approximately 15MB in size will cause a browser error on Chrome, or will simply never complete the upload process in Firefox . In Chrome, after selecting a mobile video larger than 15MB to upload, the progress bar never appears and within about 15 seconds Chrome will throw an "Aw, Snap! Something went wrong while displaying this webpage..." error. In Firefox, after selecting a mobile video to upload larger than 15MB, the progress bar will appear, but no indication of upload activity will be evident and the process never completes. Obviously, in both cases Mobile uploads will fail. Since it is possible to turn on the mobile upload processing error, and turn it off, by enabling and disabling the FFMPEG conversion settings in the Poodll filter, I assume that the root issue is with the filter and not my environment, but I would appreciate some other perspectives or troubleshooting  suggestions on the matter. Moodle is running on a Debian (Jesse) instance, with 2GB of RAM, 60GB HD, and PHP.INI settings that allow up tp 512MB uploads and 640MB of script memory. Regards; Michael

Forum Post: 
Post title: PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins
Post description: After a fair bit of consideration I recently made the decision that PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins. i.e. it won't be free. PoodLL has had great uptake from the Moodle community and the users have been positive through the good times, and patient and understanding through trouble times. So going premium is not something I have taken likely. At its heart is the reality that PoodLL needs a lot of work to make the full transition to HTML5 and for a host of other feature improvements and better support options (incl. documentation). You can read more on an this here: http://poodll.com/?p=2107 It will be available as an annual subscription with 3 tiers of membership: i) individual teacher (aka little guy) ii) single institution/organization iii) partner The pricing and some other details are yet to be decided, but from now on there will be more no more updates published on Moodle.org or the existing GitHub repositories, other than bug and security fixes. In the past I maintained a mailing list of PoodLL users, but these days that list doesn't contain the large majority of users. So currently there is no direct way for me to communicate with the PoodLL user base.  It would be very helpful for me if as a PoodLL user you could take this quick 8 question survey. https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/63DJ529

Forum Post: 
Post title: An error occured, your file has NOT been submitted
Post description: Nobody likes to see this. But what should you check when it happens? Well first of all its a general error. And it tells you/the student that your recording will not be saved. That is important. At this point your recording is already gone. There is probably nothing you can do but re record. Things to check i) is the microphone capturing sound? Or the video camera capturing your picture. If not, then there is nothing to submit or convert. And you might get this error. ii) does a very short recording get submitted ok? Sometimes longer recordings have problems at the server or browser level. iii) what recorder are you using? The two audio recorders look similar but are completely different. The video one is different again but in terms of troubleshooting its identical to the red5 audio recorder. MP3 recorder: recordings get less reliable as they get longer. Best not to venture over 2 mins. conversion to MP3 happens before the upload . If the file is too big it might spin forever and give up if the upload begins but throws an error, the connection to the Moodle server is problematic. Check the browser console for errors related to the file being posted. Some servers restrict the upload file size. Thats a whole new ball game, but if thats the case small uploads will be working. audio recorder/video recorder (red5): if you can't play it back after recording.... then the file never arrived on the Red5 server. Check the connection lamp on the recorder. Should be green. If its red or yellow your connection is bad (firewall? ) or the red5 server is down (happens.) If you can play it back, but get the error message above ... then the problem is that your file can't be collected from the Red5 server and copied back into Moodle. Turn off auto convert to mp3/mp4 in the filter settings and try again (or uncheck the mp3/mp4 checkbox on the recorder BEFORE recording). If conversion is the issue then its best to set up FFMPEG on the Moodle server and have PoodLL do its magic with that. Check the port settings in the PoodLL filter settings for HTTP. Your Moodle server will need to be able to do a server to server connection to that port on the  Red5 server to pick up the recorded file.

Forum Post: 
Post title: PoodLL and Flash
Post description: Yesterday Adobe Flash was getting death threats from Facebook and getting blocked by Firefox , after news of not just security errors, but in the wild exploits,  came to light. PoodLL uses Adobe Flash mainly for audio/video recording, but it can be turned off if need be. Flash can also be turned off for the widgets, players and whiteboards. Information on how to do that is here: http://poodll.com/flash-and-poodll/ In short, in the PoodLL filter settings, widgets, players and recorders can be limited to HTML5 only in the "When to use HTML5" section. The default whiteboard can be selected in the "Whiteboard settings" section. N.B. The non flash whiteboards (LiterallyCanvas and DrawingBoard.js) are not working properly in Moodle 2.9 yet. I am not actually advising anyone to turn Flash off. I will leave that to people more knowledgeable than me. But if you are in a situation where you cannot use Flash, the above settings should do the job.

Post title: Proctored Poodll for a Single quiz course?
Post description: We have created a dev site and plan to use Moodle and Poodll in a specific and limited way: to allow Users to choose a Course that is One Quiz, and we record their test-taking as a proctored system. If and when they pass, they get a grade VALUE that is in the range of 0 to 1000. We are using the latest versions, Moodle 2.6 etc, on a modern server (Rochen) Specifics, User Pathway/experience 1. The User sees a list of courses, renamed as “___ Tests”. Each Course consists of one Quiz; when completed they have completed the Course. 2. User chooses to take Quiz, then ideally they are auto-enrolled(? they are already registered and logged in, so can we do this?) . 3. They see preface screen to the test, showing them test-taking info and links, advisories about the test, etc. 4. They start the fifteen minute timed quiz. The video tapes them automatically and they see the recorder (themselves) on screen. A proctor will review it, to compare it to "face on file", and to prevent cheating in several ways (looking at notes, asking someone for answers, etc). 3. Those videos are then deleted, unless there is a controversy. The effort so far: Thanks in advance, and my apologies if we missed something obvious! Greg

Post title: PoodLL Cheat Sheet
Post description: Here is a cheat sheet of most (not all) of the PoodLL filter string types. I have been meaning to do this for *years* but rashly promised to do it today to a webinar. So it is done. Not all the options for each type are listed, but the main ones are. The URL is here: http://www.cheatography.com/justinhunt/cheat-sheets/poodll-filter/ The PDF download is attached to this forum post, but in the future you should get the latest from the url above. For those who don't know what this is all about, Poodll has a whole bunch of widgets that can be inserted into Moodle. eg a stopwatch. You do that by inserting a crafty little string that looks like this: {POODLL:type=stopwatch} which turns into stopwatch when you view the activity. The cheat sheet contains information about those crafty filter strings. You can play around, and see them, over at http://demo.poodll.com **NB DON'T COPY AND PASTE THE FILTER STRINGS** The encoding of the text on the PDF and cheatsheet website is wrong. Even without that, invisible html characters often sneak in and break things. Just type the strings out longhand. Enjoy *edited 19/06/2014 added warning about copy/paste and file encoding*

Post title: VIdeoEasy disable video autoplay

That is in the same location of the site administration as the General settings page

Forum Post: 
Post title: Privacy (Poodll Cloud)
Post description: Hello, We are planning to use Poodll and we are specially interested in automatic phonetic correction which is a great feature. I understand the technology is based on Amazon software and data are stoured in the cloud. Can you tell me if this data (students voices) is acced by third parties, Amazon for instance, where the servers are (ie under what laws) /what kind of privacy policiy is applied? Thank you very much for your help!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ulrike The data that is sent and stored on Amazon is just voice data. Usernames, email addresses and even the Moodle userid are not stored there. You have a choice of servers, Tokyo, USA (north east), Sydney, Dublin. If you use the Dublin server then it is the EU and GDPR applies. Poodll has a privacy policy, here: https://support.poodll.com/en/support/solutions/articles/19000079274-poodll-user-data-and-gdpr Note also that Poodll supports the Moodle Privacy API so you can manage your requirements using that. I hope that helps
Comment 2: Hello Justin, Yes, indeed - thank you very much for your answer (and the good news)! Ulrike

Post title: Warning -dumb question
Post description: Moodle 3.72 query This looks fabulous - but just a little worried about storage implications with 10,000 students. 1. Is the teachers marking Audio or video feedbakc hosted on the same server of offloaded elsewhere? 2. If it is on the moodle HTML server does this terrific tool allow the video or audio files to be hosted else where off server? eg free file hosting services? 3. MOST IMPORTANTLY - does this have an expiry for the feedback files to be stored - or to auto-delete after playback by the learner (I know what you're thinking "this message will self destruct" etc) but  I need to know about lifecycle management of rich media as 4 meg feedback x 10-20 feedbacks per year x 1000 (never mind) 10000 students is a concern... Any and all feedback welcome (especially if your answers follow the 1,2,3 numbering!!) Dom
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Dom, I know we have talked recently over email. But let me answer here too. Sorry to be  a bit late. 1) Either. Cloud Poodll saves them in the Poodll's cloud. Classic Poodll saves them in your Moodle's data directory. 2) You can not configure 3rd party storage in Poodll. But you do have the basic choice outlined in 1) 3) Cloud Poodll has configurable file expiry at the site or activity level (depending on the plugin). Classic Poodll does not. Its a good idea though.

Post title: Read Aloud - title change not reflected in gradebook setup
Post description: I noticed something strange today in 3.5 - when I change the title of an existing Read Aloud activity, I DO see the change take place on the course page. However, the OLD name still appears in the grade book setup. Even if I edit the activity on the grsdebook set up page, the old name is shown as the title, but if I then go and edit the activity from the course page, it displays the new name as the title. Ever seen something like that?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hmm. Its probably to do with caching. When you edit it from the course page, Moodle likely refreshes the cached activity names. Presumably we could also do that in the activity itself.
Comment 2: While in gradebook setup, I purged my browser cache and moodle cache (click the "purge all caches" button in Site administration / ▶︎ Development / ▶︎ Purge all caches . So if this is being oddly behaved, I'll open up a support ticket. Just wanted to see if there was something on my end I could do to self correct.
Comment 3: Ok so if I click edit - edit settings in Gradebook set up , AND THEN click save, then the new titles gets pushed to the grade book. This work around works for the time being.

Forum Post: 
Post title: PoodLL Feedback tool - only audio available
Post description: Hi everyone, I just configured the PoodLL assignment feedback tool, and the audio feedback is there and working well.  I don't have a video option, however, and I believe I should also be able to submit video feedback just like audio.  I checked and double-checked my configurations, but can't seem to find anything out of sorts. Can someone direct me how to enable the video Feedback PoodLL?  Thanks! David
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Have you been to Site administration > Plugins > Activity modules > Assignment > Feedback plugins > Feedback PoodLL, and made sure that for, Recorders to enable, you have Video Recorder enabled? The other place to check is edit your assignment activity, scroll down to the Feedback types, and for PoodLL Recorder Type, set it to Video Recorder.
Comment 2: Thanks, AL - that's exactly what I was missing.  I appreciate the help on such a simple question! Is there a way to dynamically (i.e., within the assignment feedback screen) switch between audio and video as an option for feedback? I went to the gear to shut off the webcam, but I don't see a way to turn that off (as a way to preserve the video option, but use only audio for a once-off, for example). Cheers, David
Comment 3: I don't think there is any way to switch except for going to the edit page for the assignment, and changing it there. Of course, if you do that, it would change it for all grading after that. A couple of things you might try: If you have the PoodLL Record Anywhere, see if you can record directly into the text box for feedback. Might not be able to do if that box is not set to allow any type of media insert/ upload . Another possibility if you have the PoodLL Repository set it up is to set the assignment to allow for feedback files. Then go through the steps to upload a file, but select the Poodll repository, make your audio or video recording, and then upload it. That's one of the things I used to do before retiring so I presume it might still work.
Comment 4: Good stuff - thanks AL.  I'll give these both a try.  I've done some basic LMS admin stuff before, but not on Moodle.  So, I'm new to the Moodle game.  I appreciate your time and good suggestions, and will get with our engineers to have those other PoodLL tools installed (I've seen them, but hadn't thought about incorporating more of them).  Cheers and thanks for a good first post conversation, David.
Comment 5: Hi David Al is  spot on with all his advice. Right now there is no elegant way to do adhoc video feedback when audio is selected as the Poodll feedback type. Its a top idea though. We are working on a new plugin a bit like this, and we might just add that feature in.
Comment 6: Thanks Justin.  I used AL's suggestions and that worked perfectly - to turn on the option I want in the Feedback Type within the named Assignment.  Indeed, it'd be great to be able to also do that on-the-fly within that feedback area of the grading screen (or, at the least, keep it as video feedback, but be able to turn off the video real-time).  I look forward to seeing what plugin you are working on! Cheers, David

Forum Post: 
Post title: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
Post description: Hi, Does anyone know of a way that I can set up a PoodLL quiz question that students can self-grade. Student reads a question Student records an answer with PoodLL Student compares their own answer to a model answer in "general Feedback" Student grades their answer (so the Teacher doesn't have to") Steps 1 through 3 are obviously already standard quiz steps. The fourth is important for me since the objective of the exercise I'm trying to build is the checking of the answer (and not necessarily the answering). I realize this is probably a general Moodle question rather than PoodLL specific, but since I got no answer in the general Moodle forums, I thought maybe another PoodLL user had experienced the same need.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Daniel, It depends on which version of Moodle you are using and even then would need testing to make sure you have things set up right. I have tried this with an essay question and a PoodLL question in a quiz, and it works. Create the quiz, then in Quiz administration click on Permissions . Scroll down to Activity: Quiz and find Grade quizzes manually . Click the + and add Student . In my testing, students were able to see and grade only their own quiz. The teacher was able to see and grade them all.
Comment 2: It works! Thank you. I've been trying to find out how to do this for ages. I'm very happy.  This will add a great deal of value to the activities I want to use it in and for the students on my course. Thank you.
Comment 3: Off hand, I can't remember which version of Moodle it was where they gave us the capability to modify the permissions for individual activities like this. The nice thing is the same "trick" of changing permissions for an activity works with other activities too, but you do have to be VERY CAREFUL as they do not necessarily limit a student to seeing and grading ONLY their own entries. Just as a personal reminder, on the few occasions that I've used this trick, I have added something to the activity name and description, such as "Self graded" just to make sure I don't accidentally duplicate and use it when and where I shouldn't.
Comment 4: Thanks. That's a useful tip. It will also help students differentiate between quizzes that are self-graded and auto-graded.

Post title: JS Error: Get Audio/Video Devices
Post description: I'm having an issue, specifically in Google Chrome, with users being able to record audio/video files within PoodLL. It appears this might be an issue with the JavaScript call to get media devices. I tested in Firefox without issue. I did change Chrome's settings to allow for camera and mic control on the site, to no avail. Below is the JavaScript error that I believe is indicating the issue: Uncaught RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) at MediaDevices.navigator.mediaDevices.getUserMedia (first.js:111) Any recommendations would be helpful. We are running Moodle 3.2.2 with PoodLL 3 (cloud hosted).
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Chase Upgrade to the latest Poodll filter and this should be fixed. You might occasionally find if you are manually unzipping files (not using git or the auto plugin install feature) that the problem file remains. In that case remove files: /filter/poodll/amd/src/gumadaptor.js /filter/poodll/amd/build/gumadaptor.min.js from the Poodll filter.
Comment 2: Thanks for the information, Justin!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Installing on 3.2
Post description: unable to install on moodle 3.2. when installing from the moodle plugin site it confirms the package then when I try to upgrade the moodle server it goes to a page that says upgrading poodll but it never goes beyound that page. I waited for almost 8 hours and it never loaded the success page. After failled install event when I close and try to log back into the site I get an internal server error and have to install a recent backup of the site before moodle will work again. To start off I changed to max execution time and other parameters and followed all the steps in getting started docs. I do not know how to debugging in moodle yet am learning from reading the docs on that right now. but want to know if this is a known problem with a fix available
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Lee That does not sound good. The most common problem is the need to raise the max execution time. I think this is because we use the Amazon AWS SDK in Poodll, and Moodle does some verification on the code, and there is a lot of code. Can you check what the reported max execution time on your site is when you visit: Site admin -> server ->php info It should be 90 or more. If you really can't get past this, I am happy to look into it for you. But in that case you should start a ticket via https://poodll.com/contact . Then we will be able to share passwords etc in private.
Comment 2: I have started a ticket thank you
Comment 3: Lee, Justin,

Any update on this issue? I was upgrading plugins in my MAMP test site and ran into the exact same issue once I tried to update Poodll. I don't have time at the moment to setup my MAMP test site at the moment but I was definitely surprised (and good to know). Running 3.2.1+ with php 7.0.16.
Comment 4: I wanted to add that I simply swapped out the Poodll package after downloading the zip, unzipping the folder, and replacing the contents so I'm not sure why there is any timeout issue. Just tried again with debugging turned on at my work MAMP set up: Fatal error : Maximum execution time of 30 seconds exceeded in C:\MAMP\htdocs\courses\lib\classes\plugin_manager.php on line 2214
Comment 5: I hate feeling like I'm spamming the forum but I just wanted to say I was able to successfully install the update after changing the php.ini max execution time to 120 in my MAMP set up. Of course, it was instant as it normally has been under the 30 s default setting. Keep up the great works. I noticed the erroneous S3 error so glad to see it addressed (wasn't an issue really anyway).
Comment 6: I am glad that raising the max execution time solved it. And thanks for reporting back. This doc explains how to set the max execution time in a bit of detail: https://poodll.com/poodll-3-docs/increasing-phps-max_execution_time/

Forum Post: Post title: Poodll video created with ipad not showing in computer browsers Post description: A very good afternoon to you all and thank you for your support of Poodll. I'm wondering if anyone might be able to help me. Some students created a Poodll video with their ipads which converted properly and was visible when the students posted it to a forum (Moodle 3.2). I saw the video playing. However, now it isn't visible. All that shows in the forum window is "upfile_468814434.mov". In the html I can see "

" which means it should be showing doesn't it? If someone could point me to what I'm doing wrong and how to fix it I'd be most grateful. Kind regards, Eric Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Hi Eric As a super Poodll 3 guy you can, and probably should, send support requests via the contact form at https://poodll.com/contact or send email directly. The reason is that in Poodll 3 there is a support info file that you can generate. That tells me all your versions and settings, and it speeds things up. Find that at: site admin -> plugins -> filters -> poodll -> support info ( I think its probably best not to attach it to forum posts. ) To answer your question. It sounds like "cloud recording" is off. In that case the mov file has not been sent to the Poodll cloud conversion service. So it is stuck a mov file. Try turning on "cloud recording" on the Poodll filter general settings page. This is really the best thing to do. You could maybe play ,mov file back as is.  As long as the player selected was good with mov files. You could try the Media Element Video player in Poodll. This page explains how to set up Video JS, but the principles are the same for Media Element Audio. https://poodll.com/poodll-3-docs/video-js/ Finally there is a Poodll App these days. Read about that here, https://poodll.com/poodll-3-docs/using-the-poodll-mobile-app/ That makes it easier to record audio/video off iOS devices. But it also works best with cloud recording. So you should have that enabled. Label:

Post title: Audio/video file remove from course but file still exist in MoodleData folder and info in Database
Post description: Audio/video files are saving in moodleData folder and 'mdl_files' table saving all info regarding files. Question is: When an audio/video file is deleting from page, it will not deleted from moodleData folder. File still exist in moodleData folder and information still in database . How to clean these unnecessary audio/video files and clean database as well?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If the files are stored in the Moodle file system, using the Moodle files API then Moodle should take care of deleting old files. This should happen periodically when the Moodle cron job is run.
Comment 2: Thank you Justin for quick reply. Question is: How Moodle will understand which file to be deleted and which file should keep?
Comment 3: Each file is stored in a file area that is associated with a context . So for example, when an assignment submission is deleted, any files in file areas associated with that context and item id are deleted (or marked for deletion). So if you save files in the way that Moodle expects , Moodle will handle all that stuff for you.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Need admin permission to  save audio/video files in remote server
Post description: Hi, To save audio/video file in remote server , we need admin user permission . That's not secured for the server. A normal user with write permission can't write file to the server. How can I solve it? How can I save audio/video file without admin  user? Thank you
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Mohammad, What is the operating system on the server? Is the audio/video file being uploaded into Moodle on the server. If so, more than likely, it is your web server user that needs the permission. For instance, my server is running CentOS 7 and apache is the web server user that has to have permission to write files.
Comment 2: Hi AL, First files are saving in the remote server ( Ubuntu ) then copied to moodle, later delete files from ubuntu server. The security risk is to write files on Ubuntu server, It needs admin user. Mvh Kabir
Comment 3: Why not see about creating a repository in your Moodle data directory and put the files there, or try using something like Drop Box?
Comment 4: The files are being written by Red5. So the user running Red5 needs to be able to write the files. To run on a port lower than 1024, by default you need root permissions I think. I am not an expert on that. But apache on your Moodle server will be just the same. So whatever is doable/acceptable there, should be possible on the Ubuntu server too. The directory to which the files are written only needs to be owned or writeable by  Red5.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Usability Issues with PoodLL
Post description: Hello we have just installed a number of PoodLL plugins on our moodle development environment in hopes of replacing nanogong and have seen some weirdness. We are running moodle 3.0.5+ on RHEL 6 with postgres DB We have installed the following PoodLL plugins: Filter ( 2.8.6(Build 2016061600)) Recording ( 2.6.0(Build 2015121100)) Assignment Submissions ( 1.5.9 (Build 2015121101)) Feedback ( 1.0.6 (Build 2015121101)) I noticed a number of warnings in the error log: [Wed Aug 17 16:42:40 2016] [error] [client x.x.x.x] File does not exist: /ROOT-DIRECTORY/moodle/mod/assign/skinvolumemeter.png, referer: https://SERVERNAME/moodle/mod/assign/view.php [Wed Aug 17 16:42:40 2016] [error] [client x.x.x.x] File does not exist: /ROOT-DIRECTORY/moodle/mod/assign/plainskinbackground.png, referer: https://SERVERNAME/moodle/mod/assign/view.php Is there some configuration issues we missed? Also, when we attempted to submit an audio assignment, the recorder would appear, the audio would be recorded and could be listened to but when submitted, the recorder showed up again on screen and the page was still loading (spinning).  I noticed a brief glance of some debug information and realized that moodle was set to debug email sending.  If I stopped the page, and went back to view the assignment, the audio was uploaded and working (blue flow player).  When I turned the debug off, it appeared to work. Also, for some reason, a tester indicated that they were unable to use the recorder but then it started working.  I know this is minimal information but is it possible that cache needed to be cleared or permissions for player needed to be accepted? Any advice would be appreciated.  If I have more additional comments, I will add them. Thanks Eric
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Eric Sorry for the slow reply. Those error messages about .png files can be ignored and they are annoying. I think I removed those in the latest version. The other issues are a bit hard to pin down. Sometimes debug and other output can get mixed up in what should be meaningful ajax responses and even into the recorded files themselves. Of course this shouldn't really happen but I have seen it before. I would consider this not a likely cause of the other problems you reported. There are many ways recording can fail, let me count the ways The recording timed out during upload The user's mic device is not recognized or not available The user has not given permission via various popup dialogs to access mic device The recording can't be uploaded due to bandwidth or network issues There are file permission issues on the PoodLL files There is a bug in PoodLL somewhere There is not really a problem, but the user thinks there is The file is recording ok, but its in a format that can't be played back The PoodLL filter settings are to convert with FFMPEG but ffmpeg is not set up PHP security settings, mod-security or suhosin are killing the file upload And that won't be all of them. So its a bit of a minefield at times. Its most likely a permissions, network or device issue. Try really short recordings, and see if they work. If they do, and big long ones don't, then try using the red5 audio recorder (ie not the mp3 one).
Comment 2: Hello all, I do not think I could explain the error so I used Snagit to create a video/audio capture.  The url is: https://portico.concordia.ca/katcher/poodll/ I will try to message you with the username and password to access the video. Thanks Eric

Forum Post: 
Post title: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
Post description: Hello Community; I am struggling to get consistent and good performance out of Poodll/Moodle specifically regarding mobile uploads of video assignments. I am evaluating Poodll in a self hosted virtual instance of Moodle, and have found that although small mobile video files under 10MB will generally upload via Poodll and play back without issue on the source device, once the file size exceeds roughly 15-20MB, then things start to fall apart. Background... My use case requires that all students will be submitting assignments via mobile device platforms, which if I understand correctly would be best served by converting submissions via FFMPEG for widest mobile platform compatibility. Therefore, I have built FFMPEG on my test server from sources, and have verified that when called from the system path, it is working correctly. I have also verified via shell command that the FFMPEG switches used on the poodll demo site are working. Therefore, I assume that the Poodll Filter settings to auto convert mobile submissions to MP4 and to use FFMPEG for the conversion are also working, although I have yet to determine how to verify this as I have not seen any entries in any server logs. Back to the problem at hand... Without FFMPEG settings enabled in the Poodll filter, files of any size, up to the server limit of 512MB, will upload from a mobile device without issue. Playback is choppy over mobile data, but plays smoothly via WiFi, suggesting that playback quality is bandwidth dependent. With FFMPEG conversion settings enabled in the Poodll filter, mobile uploads above approximately 15MB in size will cause a browser error on Chrome, or will simply never complete the upload process in Firefox . In Chrome, after selecting a mobile video larger than 15MB to upload, the progress bar never appears and within about 15 seconds Chrome will throw an "Aw, Snap! Something went wrong while displaying this webpage..." error. In Firefox, after selecting a mobile video to upload larger than 15MB, the progress bar will appear, but no indication of upload activity will be evident and the process never completes. Obviously, in both cases Mobile uploads will fail. Since it is possible to turn on the mobile upload processing error, and turn it off, by enabling and disabling the FFMPEG conversion settings in the Poodll filter, I assume that the root issue is with the filter and not my environment, but I would appreciate some other perspectives or troubleshooting  suggestions on the matter. Moodle is running on a Debian (Jesse) instance, with 2GB of RAM, 60GB HD, and PHP.INI settings that allow up tp 512MB uploads and 640MB of script memory. Regards; Michael
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Michael Make sure that transcoding is going on in the background (there is a switch for that on the settings page). This will mean that the browser won't wait for the transcoding to finish. It relies on cron to kick off the transcoding. So it won't start till cron runs. Though it does sound like the real issue is with uploading. There are settings that affect uploads on your web server. Apache mod_security and the PHP extension suhosin are two of those. I would look into that. Both of those by default limit the size and nature of uploads.
Comment 2: Thank you Justin; I have tried mobile submissions with the Background trans-coding option enabled and disabled, with no noticeable difference. So I will enable it again, but as you suggest the problem is likely to be elsewhere. I will investigate mod_security and suhosin. Hopefully I can find some clues there. Regards, Mike Somerville
Comment 3: Hello Justin; I guess I should have known this already, but Suhosin and Mod_Security are not installed on my Debian virtual server. Can you think of any other areas/log files that I can inspect to continue troublshooting?
Comment 4: Sorry Michael, I will reply to your email today. I apologize for the delay. It sounds like you are hitting some sort of upload limit. The usual suspects are suhosin and mod_security. In php.ini there are also: memory_limit upload_max_filesize post_max_size Apparently the values of those should follow this pattern: upload_max_filesize =< post_max_size =< memory_limit So the simple way is to make them all the same, but upload_max_filesize should never be greater then post max_size, which should never be greater then memory_limit. I am not an expert in this, though I have learned the hard way about some of it. Another thing you might try is recording over at https://demo.poodll.com . This is using the new PoodLL3 and Amazon S3 for uploads. If that all works for you, perhaps PoodLL3 would be a good solution

Forum Post: 
Post title: PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins
Post description: After a fair bit of consideration I recently made the decision that PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins. i.e. it won't be free. PoodLL has had great uptake from the Moodle community and the users have been positive through the good times, and patient and understanding through trouble times. So going premium is not something I have taken likely. At its heart is the reality that PoodLL needs a lot of work to make the full transition to HTML5 and for a host of other feature improvements and better support options (incl. documentation). You can read more on an this here: http://poodll.com/?p=2107 It will be available as an annual subscription with 3 tiers of membership: i) individual teacher (aka little guy) ii) single institution/organization iii) partner The pricing and some other details are yet to be decided, but from now on there will be more no more updates published on Moodle.org or the existing GitHub repositories, other than bug and security fixes. In the past I maintained a mailing list of PoodLL users, but these days that list doesn't contain the large majority of users. So currently there is no direct way for me to communicate with the PoodLL user base.  It would be very helpful for me if as a PoodLL user you could take this quick 8 question survey. https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/63DJ529
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Justin, I wish you well with this.  I am sure it will be a success, and I think such developments are inevitable, with or without what we may call "official" support from MoodleHQ. On a completely different but related matter, I was reminded of the thread earlier on plugins.  I am still of the opinion that alongside the plugin/premium ecosystem we have talked about, we need a "Givealittle" style option. I found my post from 17th June here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=314916#p1263153 I think I will give this a little bump. My view remains unchanged: " As a first off, I'd like someone to make it easy for us to "give a little" to any developer with a plugin in the database .  Quite apart from any of the complex plans and programmes you have thought about" I will watch developments with interest Justin. -Derek
Comment 2: Thanks Derek. I think thats a good initiative, and I hope Moodle HQ implement it. For myself personally I found taking donations got very tricky because Paypal stopped doing donation buttons in Japan. Something on the plugins database would be nice
Comment 3: Hi Justin, I can understand and sympathise with your thinking. Having read through the discussion you cited, I'd certainly subscribe to the "pay the developer directly" camp.  I would be very unhappy at the prospect of paying into a pool which gets distributed by someone else. I hope that you get enough institutions on board to allow you to keep the price very low for individual teachers - they are the ones who don't have the IT backup to get round the problems that your plugins solve so elegantly! All the best Andy
Comment 4: Thanks Andy. Pricing is going to be tricky, but I definitely want to keep it affordable for teachers. J
Comment 5: Any rough time frame for the next release? HTML5 recording is important to us.
Comment 6: HTML5 recording will likely be ready December I think. There will be some releases along the way though I hope.
Comment 7: Hi Justin Any update on PoodLL 3 May 2016 release?
Comment 8: We are shooting for July 14th (2016) Working hard. J
Comment 9: Exciting ;)
Comment 10: Now it's july 14th, and always nothing about poodll 3. I begin to be really exciting. Please stop to play with my nerves...
Comment 11: You are correct. And I apologise I am still making some changes and testing. It is not a good idea to announce a release date I realise now. Actually I am very pleased with how PoodLL3 is coming together. And it will be released in a day or two. But I think it would be wise to not install it on a production site just yet. I will prepare more information from now.

Post title: Audio recording assignment not working in Firefox
Post description: Hi there, I've just installed the latest version of the filter and the online assignment plugins in my Moodle 3.0.1 site, so students can submit assignments by recording themselves. It all works flawlessly on Chrome and Edge, but on Firefox (v43.0.4, the latest one with the latest flash plugin), it doesn't work. I can start the recording (after giving Flash permission to use my microphone), I then proceed to stop it and I see an "uploading" spinning symbol, but when it finishes the recording hasn't been actually saved, nothing plays when I click on the play button of the plugin, or when I save the supposedly recorded audio and use the media player to listen to it. Not even if I submit the assignment. One thing I can tell is different from when I try this same action on Chrome and Edge is that on those browsers, while I speak, the volume bar in the plugin shows feedback (with green and red bars), while on Firefox that doesn't happen. I've been able to test this in a couple computers running Windows 10 and the latest version of Firefox, both with exact same results. In those same computers, using Chrome or Edge works fine. Is this some sort of bug in Firefox (or the plugin) not actually enabling the microphone? Any way around it? Thanks so much in advance for any feedback, this plugin is awesome! Edit: I forgot to mention that I also tried with the audio submission example in the Poodll demo site ( http://demo.poodll.com/mod/assign/view.php?id=87&action=view ) with same exact results, so it's not something related to my Moodle site or my server ...
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Albert, We had the same problem with the audio recorder. Try going into your Firefox' "Add-ons" >  "Plugins" and go to the "Options" for the "Shockwave Flash" plugin. There should be a checkbox for "Protected Mode" or something similar. Uncheck it and try again with the audio recorder! This is rather unfortunate as Firefox gives a notice about the missing plugin without Flash - but then things only get worse after installing Flash, as now the recorder shows up but doesn't work.
Comment 2: The same problem with Firefox 44.0.2. "Protected mode" is unchecked but audio recorder doesn't work. Is there any other solution? Thank you!

Post description: Hello We are using poodll for moodle 2.8.3+, and we are experiencing several issues on mobile compatibility even with html5 enabled for mobile support and on desktop. On android (tested it with samsung galaxy tab 3 )  : -Default browser (android browser) TINYMCE Sometimes the upload or record file button do not appear we can record videos but when we want to upload it we are logged out of moodle the witheboard is unusable, seems like it does'nt recognize the exact place i want to draw There is no way to record an audio file the only option is to upload a file ATTO we can record videos and upload it but we cannot read it on the same browser the witheboard is unusable, seems like it does'nt recognize the exact place i want to draw There is no way to record an audio file the only option is to upload a file - firefox for android Only tested with ATTO with default browser for videos :  we are logged out when uploading videos the witheboard is ok we can record an audio file but when uploading the file in moodle we are logged out Desktop  : chrome on ubuntu When we finish and stop recording on our red5 server the device is still sending requests to red5 Our teachers sended us a report with compatibility issues they experienced : we solved some of them changing the parameters of poodll filter in the admins setting but we was not able to reproduce evrything . I linked the file they send us We installed ffmpeg in the moodle server and we activated the conversion options. Maybe our version of poodll is buggy. Here is what we are using $plugin->version   = 2015070401; $plugin->requires  = 2011070100.00; $plugin->component = 'filter_poodll'; $plugin->maturity  = MATURITY_STABLE; $plugin->release   = '2.7.6(Build 2015070401)'; Can you please help us improve realibility of our poodll installation ? Mamadou
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That is not the latest version of PoodLL.  However the later versions are only for Moodle 2.9 and greater. But even if you did upgrade you will still experience some of those problems. Files recorded on your device will not necessarily play back in the same device's browser. For example iPhone records mov files, and Android records different file types depending on the device model. But those are mostly rotten for use in a web environment. PoodLL can't do much about that, except to receive the recordings and then convert them to a better format. You will need to convert them using FFMPEG to a file format that can be played back generically. By email last year I sent you notes on the FFMPEG setup. The javascript whiteboards should work, but there were issues in Moodle 2.8 with Literally Canvas, so please try drawingboard.js. It is one of the options in the PoodLL filter settings. Regarding being logged out when trying to upload, I have heard of this but have not had a chance to look into yet. Justin
Comment 2: Hello Justin, Thanks for your feedback. will try the drawingboard.js. I'll look closely to the file you sent me (definitly forgot about that one oops ! ) There is something in the poodll-red5-webapp (as we are not using tokyo.poodll.com ) that is not compatible with the mp4 conversion in moodle When we activate the ffmpeg conversion for videos in moodle server and we use flash recording to our red5 server,  poodll tries to download from red5 server a mp4 file but it does not call the conversion function before. so there is a flv file but no mp4 file. And I didn't see any error message. we just notice that when accessing to the course that we cannot se the video. I was working on something else and as we are about to update i didn't know if your proposal would be very useful for us. have a nice day Mamadou

Post title: An error occured, your file has NOT been submitted
Post description: Nobody likes to see this. But what should you check when it happens? Well first of all its a general error. And it tells you/the student that your recording will not be saved. That is important. At this point your recording is already gone. There is probably nothing you can do but re record. Things to check i) is the microphone capturing sound? Or the video camera capturing your picture. If not, then there is nothing to submit or convert. And you might get this error. ii) does a very short recording get submitted ok? Sometimes longer recordings have problems at the server or browser level. iii) what recorder are you using? The two audio recorders look similar but are completely different. The video one is different again but in terms of troubleshooting its identical to the red5 audio recorder. MP3 recorder: recordings get less reliable as they get longer. Best not to venture over 2 mins. conversion to MP3 happens before the upload . If the file is too big it might spin forever and give up if the upload begins but throws an error, the connection to the Moodle server is problematic. Check the browser console for errors related to the file being posted. Some servers restrict the upload file size. Thats a whole new ball game, but if thats the case small uploads will be working. audio recorder/video recorder (red5): if you can't play it back after recording.... then the file never arrived on the Red5 server. Check the connection lamp on the recorder. Should be green. If its red or yellow your connection is bad (firewall? ) or the red5 server is down (happens.) If you can play it back, but get the error message above ... then the problem is that your file can't be collected from the Red5 server and copied back into Moodle. Turn off auto convert to mp3/mp4 in the filter settings and try again (or uncheck the mp3/mp4 checkbox on the recorder BEFORE recording). If conversion is the issue then its best to set up FFMPEG on the Moodle server and have PoodLL do its magic with that. Check the port settings in the PoodLL filter settings for HTTP. Your Moodle server will need to be able to do a server to server connection to that port on the  Red5 server to pick up the recorded file.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Justin, I have a student who claims the PoodLL MP3 recorder does not pick up his microphone (which, he claims, works fine otherwise). He can save recordings, but they have zero length and thus do not play. He claims to have tried different browsers, different microphone settings and has the latest version of Flash. Can you give a suggestion as to what I might look into. The others in the course manage to record. Rgrds, Paul.
Comment 2: I think your student has probably unwittingly denied permission to the recorder to access the microphone. Depending on the browser there are two places permissions need to be granted. Flash will show a permissions dialog which can be reshown by right clicking over the recorder and selecting "settings" or "properties". Chrome and other browsers may have their own permissions dialogs which will be shown after flash tries to access the mic. Other things to check might include that the microphone is plugged in, or if there are multiple microphones in the machine, that the correct one is selected. (again right click ->settings and choose the microphone tab ). Occasionally it is necessary to mess with the microphone tab settings there to spark the microphone into action. I do not know why. Flash is a black box in that regard.

Post title: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
Post description: I've been using the PoodLL mp3 audio recorder in the Atto text editor on my Moodle 2.9 system and the recording seems to go fine. I save it and whenever I go to play it back, I usually only get an audio clip of 4 to 12 seconds long, even if the recording was a minute or two. Does anyone have any suggestions or solutions?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have seen this before, and I am trying to recall what caused it. It may be a PHP thing called Suhosin interfering with your uploaded audio data. Go to site admin -> server ->php info. Do a search (ctrl + f) for 'suhosin' and also look at 'post_max_size' and 'upload_max_filesize.' If suhosin is there, it is the most likely culprit. And you will need to configure it to accept larger upload sizes. If its not there, then its nor the problem. If either of the other 2 values are really small, ie less than 2M, then that might be the problem. But thats unlikely.
Comment 2: I checked to see if suhosin was there but it's not. The post_max_size and upload_max_filesize are both 1024M. It's strange because the video recorder for example works perfectly. I've recorded up too 3 minutes of video and it all comes up when it's saved.
Comment 3: The Video and Red5 audio recorders work very differently to the MP3 recorder. So its not so surprising the behaviour is different. The MP3 recorder posts the data to the server, which the other recorders don't do. Something is truncating the uploaded data. I am not sure what is doing it, but anything that limits the upload file size would be something to look at. If it works for you, you might try using the Red5 audio recorder as a workaround
Comment 4: I'll give the Red5 recorder a try but I seem to remember a similar problem with it. When you say server, do you mean the tokyo.poodll.com server? Do you think installing FFMPEG might help with this issue?
Comment 5: Installing FFMPEG , and configuring PoodLL to use it, is a good thing to do. But that is really about file conversion. And I don't think that is a solution to this problem. Something is limiting the file upload size on your Moodle server. There is no "upload" from browser to Moodle server when using tokyo.poodll.com. The browser uploads to tokyo.poodll.com. And then your Moodle server downloads it from there. That is why it is unaffected.
Comment 6: Ok, that makes sense. I'll talk to our Moodle host and ask them to investigate if there's something limiting the upload size. Thanks for your help Justin, it really is a great plugin.

Post title: PoodLL Issues
Post description: An instructor asked students to use the voice recorder enabled for them via PoodLL's plug-in within Moodle. One of the biggest problems is that it was very confusing for students because they couldn't tell if their audio actually submitted, as no notification was given, and after saving, they can't see the file there, or listen back to it. The instructor had the same problem in leaving voice feedback for students. Is there anyway for students and instructors to listen to files after they've been submitted? Or for instance if an instructor uses PoodLL to give feedback and two weeks later wants to hear it to remember what they said can they? Currently that doesn't seem available.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Clint That should certainly be possible. I wonder how you are doing these things. Perhaps you are doing it a different way than most, or the recording is not working at all. The recorder does allow you to playback the recorded file, and should display an "uploading" dialog. And after the page hosting the recorder has been saved, there should be a player (audio or video) in the feedback area for the student ( or on the submission summary if its an assignment submission). And when the teacher returns to the page they should see a recorder for re-recording and a player for listening to the existing feedback recording. If none of that is happening, it should be, and so there is some problem at your end.

Post title: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
Post description: Our program is considering the Poodll Plug-ins, and one critical requirement we have of our coursework is accessibility . I am interested in the community's feedback on Poodll's usability and functions for people who are visually or hearing impaired. Putting aside the complications of audio and video assignments and feedback for a moment (we know we have a lot of work to help class members and instructors provide accessible content for each other ), please comment on the usability of the tools themselves. From the videos I am seen of Poodll in action the buttons and links appear as accessible or inaccessible as any other Moodle module.  Do you or your users report a different experience? Thanks for your thoughts. Robin Sitten Perkins eLearning
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Robin, it would be interesting indeed to see what others have to say on this. But I have to say that it is probably not the best news. I battled for some time to make the buttons visible to screen readers and in the end found that it was not going to work ... because of limitations of the framework I originally wrote the recorders in. Though it did not occur to me then, since that time I have found a way around those limitations and have implemented it in one of the recorders. Basically by hiding the flash widget and handling all user interaction via html buttons and javascript a far more accessible interface can be made. Effectively we are introducing skinning to PoodLL. It is just a matter of finding the time, to get it all done. But accessibility goes beyond just screen readers, so any comments or advice would be welcome.
Comment 2: Hi Robin, I was just browsing information about Poodll on Moodle.or and found your post and one other which didn't seem to address the issue. I've been working on Poodll in Moodle 2.8 and found that this plugin is not accessible. When I ran the NVDA screen reader and also sent a sample to our disability officer which is blind, he was unable to detect the player. The screen reader bypasses this alltogether. I will be sending a request to the developers to review this plug in and help us to comply with WCAG 2.0. Cheers, Nora Colazzo
Comment 3: You are right that much of it is not accessible. Luckily its not far away for the most popular of the components however. I was able to introduce full skinning for the MP3 audio recorder last month, thanks to "The Learning Factory" in Brazil. That makes adding accessibility to the MP3 recorder relatively simple. The other recorders require similar work, but at least we have a pattern to go with. The part that is not simple in all this for me, is exactly what the normal/desired behaviour of an screen reader, especially when it encounters an audio recorder. I was quite puzzled when I was testing with JAWS previously.

Post title: PoodLL and Flash
Post description: Yesterday Adobe Flash was getting death threats from Facebook and getting blocked by Firefox , after news of not just security errors, but in the wild exploits,  came to light. PoodLL uses Adobe Flash mainly for audio/video recording, but it can be turned off if need be. Flash can also be turned off for the widgets, players and whiteboards. Information on how to do that is here: http://poodll.com/flash-and-poodll/ In short, in the PoodLL filter settings, widgets, players and recorders can be limited to HTML5 only in the "When to use HTML5" section. The default whiteboard can be selected in the "Whiteboard settings" section. N.B. The non flash whiteboards (LiterallyCanvas and DrawingBoard.js) are not working properly in Moodle 2.9 yet. I am not actually advising anyone to turn Flash off. I will leave that to people more knowledgeable than me. But if you are in a situation where you cannot use Flash, the above settings should do the job.

Post title: Poodll on ipad
Post description: A very good morning to you Justin and all. I'm using Poodll on 2.7.2 and believe I have all the filters etc properly in place and working with Poodll above the mulimedia filter on the list of filters. When I record a video with my ipad it seems to go into the forum but then it appears as a black box with a play button on it. When I try to play it I receive an empty white box. That is on both the ipad and in firefox on a mac. Wondering if anyone else is having such problems or knows why I am? Sorry to bother you but would be most grateful for any assistance. Kind regards, Eric
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Eric I just tested it on the http://demo.poodll.com where it is working. I tried to reproduce the situation you describe by playing with a few settings, but I was unable to. So I think that most likely the cause of the problem is in the recording/ upload . Are you using PoodLL Anywhere on the Editor Toolbar (Atto or TinyMCE)? Or are you using the PoodLL Repository? Or are you doing something else? If you are using PoodLL to record/upload, does it state the file was uploaded successfully? Finally does doing a much shorter/smaller recording, of say 5 seconds, work?
Comment 2: Many thanks for getting back to me so quickly Justin, Are you using PoodLL Anywhere on the Editor Toolbar (Atto)? => It is on Atto. Or are you using the PoodLL Repository?  Not sure what this is but I think not. Or are you doing
something else? Don't believe I am. If you are using PoodLL to record/upload, does it state the file was uploaded successfully?  => It does state the file was uploaded successfully. Finally does doing a much shorter/smaller recording, of say 5 seconds, work? => The tests I were doing were all 5 seconds or less. Recording from my mac worked but didn't from the ipad. Sorry to bother, but any other ideas would be very much appreciated.
Comment 3: If you are using PoodLL Anywhere for Atto, you are not using the repository, or "anything else." The repository is the system you go through using the regular moodle media button (ie choosing from google docs, youtube, wikimedia, upload a file etc) You can use FFMPEG on your Moodle server to auto convert uploaded files to MP4. I am pretty sure you have not set up that, so I think we can ignore that avenue. Let me know if I am wrong though. So the files Moodle is attempting to play will be .mov files. Flowplayer should play those back fine. As of course, should the iPad. But I have seen it go wrong. I would really need to see the uploaded file to check. So here are two things to try. i) turn off the PoodLL filter, and try to reload the page and play the video. Does it work? If so, PoodLL is messing up the playback somehow. If it still doesn't play .. lets do ii) ii) Turn the poodll filter back on. And turn on "show download link" beside players  in the PoodLL filter settings. Then there should be a download link by the player when the page is loaded. Download the file to your desktop. Can you play it there? If not, can you post it to me here, or by email, so I can look at it?
Comment 4: Thanks again Justin, Will send you those this evening as I don't have wifi for my ipad at the moment. Sorry to bother you, and as always, many thanks. Eric
Comment 5: Good evening again Justin, I turned off the Poodll plugin and refreshed the screen on the ipad. This time I get a play button with a slash through it. Am sending you the file by mail as it won't play with quicktime or VLC. Thank you very much for your assistance. Eric
Comment 6: Eric That .mov file was empty, and that is the heart of the problem. I don't like asking you to jump through all these hoops, but here are two more. Sorry. Can you try the same thing into the "forum(with video)" activity on http://demo.poodll.com ? (login creds are on the front page ) If it works there, it is a server specific thingy we need to figure out. There might be an error in your logs. If you can find the error log that apache generates, check it and see if there are any recent errors that look related. It can be necessary to turn off or configure a thing called Suhosin. And your server's maximum file upload size could also be a part of the problem. If we are at this point and there is no good error in your server logs, it gets quite complicated unfortunately. If it doesn't work on demo.poodll.com I think that maybe PoodLL has in issue with receiving uploads from your ipad. One thing that I have seen occur, is when people select "choose existing video" from the popup dialog, rather than "take a video." The uploaded file is compressed and this can cause problems with the browser/server interaction. The best reply right now to this is to recommend people select "take a video."

Comment 11: I know that this is very late (happened upon it while reading about Poodll), but the upside-down video may just be that the ipad/iphone was being held "upside down" when taking the video. My understanding is that the camera has a definite orientation (Home button should be either down for portrait orientation or on right for landscape), but will flip the preview of the video or photo if held upside down. This flipping will continue if viewing the photo or video on an Apple device. When viewed on other systems - that don't read or understand the encoded "flip this image" instructions, the image is displayed as it was recorded - upside down. This became more of a problem when Apple enabled the volume buttons to act as the shutter release. This made it more natural to hold the phone with the shutter release (volume) on top - like a camera. Which is really upside-down. David
Comment 12: I started getting weirdness myself on iPhone iOS 8.0.0. After a bit of digging it indeed turns out there was a bug in Mobile Safari that was fixed in iOS 8.0.2 . After I upgraded, bingo it all worked again. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25790873/uploading-files-over-http-fails-on-ios-8-0-0-gm-safari So that is another thing to check when you have iOS uploading woes.

Post title: HTML5 audio input - specific issue, general questions
Post description: Hi Justin, Possibly related to the Ipad thread ? I tested audio input on an Android phone (4.1.2) and got a similar issue. Uploading an existing mp3 was OK. Using a voice recording app said that the generated mp3 uploaded successfully, but Flowplayer won't play it. General questions: When using the HTML5 recording for audio, the Red5 server isn't needed, correct? It's up to the device to provide a file of type audio, and if FFMPEG conversion is installed/configured, that's what translates an ogg or wav to mp3? Is audio likely to be problematic for iPads in the way Eric was experiencing in the other thread? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Hilary. Yes, you are pretty much correct. Red5 is not used when recording with iPads and other mobile devices. The device usually has a "record now or choose an existing file" type of file upload dialog. That is out of our control. In the case of iOS there is no "record audio" option on that dialog. Just record video. And yes, that means it is hard to predict the file type that will be arriving, though in the case of iOS it is .mov. FFMPEG does the conversion if it is installed and configured. Most PoodLL/Moodles don't have it installed I suspect. Is Audio likely to be problematic, as in Eric's experience. All I can say is "maybe."  As I said in that thread, I now feel that the file upload approach, at least in the way that I have implemented it, is too fragile. The possibility of a student having a device I have not tested on, or sending up a file that doesn't convert, or that doesn't make it through the upload , is quite real. I hope to re work things in the very near future, but for now I think we should assume that recording with mobile devices needs to be handled carefully.
Comment 2: Thanks, Justin, that's very helpful. So the issue seems to be that PoodLL calling FFMPEG is not working for me. I do have it installed on my server and it works from the command line. For example, I can transform an ogg file to mp3. However, when I submit the same file via a quiz, it shows conversion ("Saved: upfile_146395184.mp3"), but the result won't play in flowplayer. When I dig into the actual file location from the hash table, it's still the ogg file (original size, & if I download & add .ogg it plays, .mp3 won't). The phone voice recorder app creates .amr files; same thing, I can translate with ffmpeg, but what PoodLL names .mp3 and stores seems to still be the amr file. I know this is labeled experimental, but is there something simple I could be missing, like file permissions? It's strange that the conversion does actually work on the one hand, and PoodLL seems to think it has successfully performed it on the other, but the result is not saved. thanks!
Comment 3: Hmm, more info... I've done testing with .mov files, and those convert and store fine! (file in filedir matches size of the manually-converted mp3) The files submitted as .ogg and .amr play on the device when reviewing the quiz. It's the non-mobile flowplayer that chokes on them.
Comment 4: Well. That is interesting. If the mov files convert to mp3 correctly. We would expect that the ogg and amr files should also. The conversion process is the same throughout PoodLL. So it is possible to do the testing for this outside the quiz. If you turn on "show download link beside players" in the PoodLL filter settings, a little download arrow will show beside the player. Even if you don't download, rolling your mouse over it should show you the url in your browser status bar. So you will see if it has in fact been converted by noting the file extension. PoodLL will first try to use the FFMPEG that it finds in the [Moodle]/filter/poodll directory. If it doesn't find one there, it will assume there is one available on the path and just bravely call "ffmpeg -i blahblah.flv blahblah.mp3" . So it is possible that the ffmpeg you are testing with and the one that PoodLL is using are not the same. It is also possible to set some parameters to the call to ffmpeg. The default is not to, but if you have some set and it might be that they work for mov but muff it for other filetypes. I have attached a document that I use to help people get up to speed with PoodLL and FFMPEG. See if anything in there helps. Also try it out on demo.poodll.com. If it works there, but not on your site, we might be able to see why. Justin
Comment 5: Hmm, very interesting comparing to demo.poodll.com and using the download link... everything seems to be exactly the same on both my site and poodll.com: The flowplayer won't play either the ogg>mp3 (displays total length 1 sec) or the amr>mp3 (length 0 sec). The link ends in mp3. Downloading the ogg>mp3 file results in a playable file. However, it is smaller (187KB) than the mp3 generated from the same file at the command line (196KB)--which is exactly the same size as the original ogg file. And actually I think it is still an ogg file... if I change the file extension it still plays in Windows Media, because I have the codec for ogg installed. Ahh, I uploaded it to TrID and that says it's indeed an .ogg. I'm attaching it, in case that helps. Downloading the supposed amr>mp3 file won't play as an mp3, but will if I change the file extension. TrID confirms it's still an amr. Also attached. .mov successfully converts to a genuine mp3, and plays in flowplayer. I tried to add "-report" in the mp3 options to get a log file on my server but can't get it working... On my server, ffmpeg is in /usr/share/, not in the PoodLL directory. But I installed it when installing PoodLL, so there's only one version to be called. It must be working in a similar fashion to the demo system, since on both .ogg and .amr don't work, but .mov does? If you get this/look at this before 9am, I'm users 06, 16, and 26 with submissions to the first audio assignment ( http://demo.poodll.com/mod/assign/view.php?action=grading&id=87 ). Thanks, Justin!
Comment 6: OK, I think I found the problem. Some file extensions were not getting converted properly. I updated the plugin, on github. Not yet on Moodle.org. Please try it and let me know if it works. https://github.com/justinhunt/moodle-filter_poodll Thanks.
