Forum Post: 
Post title: Installing PoodLL
Post description: Hi I'm trying to install the entire PoodLL 2 with the PoodLL (ALL) download . The instructions say to upload and unzip the folder to Moodle's main directory. It goes on to say "All of the components are already in their necessary directories and should arrive in the right place" and that "Moodle will set up most of the specific elements of PoodLL for you. We just have to let Moodle know we installed it. To do this, after you have copied the PoodLL modules, make sure you are logged in as admin, and click “notifications” in the site administration block. Moodle should recognize that several plugins need installing. It will recognize four new mods(filter, assignment type, question type and repository) and guide you through several install pages." Problem is Moodle hasn't recognised the plugins and I can't get on with the rest of the set up that follows this initial upload. Do I need to move any of the plugin folders somewhere else from the poodllall_2013022200 folder I've uploaded. Any pointers would be much appreciated. Thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Maybe slightly mis-read: " upload and unzip the folder IN Moodle's main directory" I think is what it should say. I'll bet if you look in the unzipped poodllall_2013022200 folder, you'll see folders like mod, block, etc..  And if you look in those you'll see something like poodllmod or poodllblock, etc.  It's the folders at that level that need to be moved to mod, block, etc.. Then one goes to notifications. Unzip the original zip locally first into a 'test' directory and see the results. 'spirit of sharing', Ken
Comment 2: Have you checked that the permissions on the folders are ok once they are in the right place? If they are still read only as sometimes seems to happen when uploading they will not be recognised. Richard
Comment 3: Carl I replied to your email. But just for anyone else who might run into this. It is a pretty common pitfall. The PoodLL all file, after it is expanded contains four folders, they should be copied over the Moodle folders of the same name. Basically you are merging them. It is just a quick way to install all 6 mods. But you can just do it mod by mod, like this: i) poodll filter : [moodle]/filter - place "/filter/poodll" directory from zip ii) online poodll assignment(2.3/2.4) : [moodle]/ mod / assign / submission - place "/mod/assign/submission/onlinepoodll" directory from zip iii) poodll online assignment(2.2 ): [moodle]/ mod /assignment/type - place "/mod/assignment/type/poodllonline" directory from zip iv) poodll recording question : [moodle]/question/type - place "/question/type/poodllrecording" directory from zip v) poodll database field : [moodle]/ mod / data / field - place "/mod/data/field/poodll" directory from zip vi) poodll repository : [moodle]/repository - place "/repository/poodll" directory from zip I hope that helps.
Comment 4: Hi Justine Sorry, I forgot to thank you for the support you provided. It was a great help. I've just upgraded to 2.6 and am re-installing the PoodLL add-ons. I notice there are now 7 rather than the 6 you list here. Do I need Assignment types, Assignment feedback and Assignment submissions? Keep up the great work - your add-ons have transformed how I use Moodle! Carl
Comment 5: Thanks Carl (again) You probably no longer need the Assignment type for (old) Moodle 2.2 assignment. The 7th mod will be PoodLL Feedback  for the (new) assignment. It allows you to record your voice/video or draw pictures as feedback for your students.
Comment 6: Got it Justin, thanks!
Comment 7: Our Moodle version 2.7 (soon to be upgrading to 2.8) is running the complete Poodll plugin set.  Now that our Moodle installation has been upgraded beyond 2.6 (and the old Assignment 2.2 activity type has been disabled and retired), the assignment_poodllonline plugin seems to no longer be required.  Deleting the plugin results in a "Missing from disk!" message on the Plugins Overview page.  As there is no Uninstall link for this plugin, what is the recommended practice for removing the obsolete plugin and the notification message?  My only remaining holdout plugins are assignment_poodllonline (and APC, but that is on my test server ).
Comment 8: I do not know why there is/was no uninstall link. To be honest, I have never really had to uninstall it. Anyway this seems to work. If you run this SQL (make sure your table name is correct) and purge caches, the message should go away. DELETE FROM `mdl_config_plugins` WHERE `mdl_config_plugins`.`plugin` = 'assignment_poodllonline'; NB: This is after you have removed any old PoodLL assignments, and removed the plugin from the filesystem.
Comment 9: Thanks, that seemed to work well on my test server!
Comment 10: Hi, I think the information Justin gave only avoid Moodle to tell "Missing from disk!", this plugin no more "registered" in mdl_config_plugins. And as he said as NB, for a real good deletion of a plugin, you should : have the plugin files installed in your Moodle,  so you have the "Uninstall" link uninstall the plugin via the link then delete plugin files HTH , Séverin

Post title: HTML5 audio player, mobile
Post description: Hi, I am having problems when trying to play back records on smarphones. The records are correctly uploaded and saved since I can play them back on computers. But It will not play back on smarphones (gs4). I am not sure if this problem is related to the poodll filter. In order to have the same player (HTML5) on both PC and smartphone, the setting "HTML5 Playback" is set to "Always use HTML5". "Auto Conv. to MP3" is set to "yes", "Convert uploaded media with FFMPEG" is set to "yes" and FFMPEG works when I try to convert using command line. The html5 player works properly on the poodll demo site when I use my smarphone. What could be responsible for this problem ? Moodle 2.5.7
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: A possible problem is trying to play back the audio file from an https url . Mobile browsers (mobile safari in particular) can be quite fussy about the certificates they accept. demo.poodll.com is not using https. This would be the first thing that I would check. If you are not running https, then try to actually download that file and confirm that it is in fact an MP3 file. Then upload it to demo.poodll.com and try playing it back from there. If it works there but not on your site, it seems likely to be a server /poodll configuration issue. If it does not play back on demo.poodll.com then it is some sort if issue with the file or how it is created.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Path for recorded  video , audio file ....Please Help Me
Post description: Hi, I am not sure if this is the right place to post this or not. If not, please let me know. 1.. I was created a page with widget of poodle ( video recorder and audio recorder ) now i want to know the path of the recorded video or audio. 2..  And i want to create a page  or link in the left navigation for list out the students from database please help me ....
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: If you want to keep the recordings made with PoodLL you really need to do so in the context of an activity which can save submissions, ie an assignment (OnlinePoodLL Assignment Submission, or a quiz (poodll recording question) or a database activity (PoodLL Database Field). A page has no save button. So just inserting a widget won't leave the recording anyway. (At least not anywhere that is accessible. ) Although you can insert a recording widget in that way, you would only do so for activities where you didn't care to keep the recording. eg practising speeches.
Comment 2: Hmm. I suppose that didn't exactly answer the question. PoodLL saves the files using Moodle's file system API. So they go into the draft files area for the activity in question (NB a "page" has no draft files area when it is being viewed). When the activity is saved, the files are moved into the file area for that activity and submission. It is quite complex and you would need to read up on it all here: https://docs.moodle.org/dev/File_API Unfortunately there is no easy to find location on disk. As for generating a list of students, I can't answer that in a sentence. It is not really clear what you are trying to do. You should look to see if there is a plugin/report that does what you want.

Post title: Creating palettes for drawings
Post description: Is it possible to create palettes for drawings, which have "snap" nodes, and provide them to students (a plugin to this plugin, of sorts)? Let me illustrate: Palette: electronic circuits Items available: MOSFET (four terminal), MOSFET (three terminal, body implicitly biased), wire (2 terminal), BJT (three terminal), resistor (two terminal), capacitor (two terminal), inductor (one terminal), op amp (3 terminal), power supply (one terminal), ground (one terminal), etc. The use experience should be that in a drawing, they should be able to drag and drop these items and connect them using the wire terminal. The terminals should correspond to "snap" point (just like tools like Omnigraffle and others have) to make it easy to connect elements. In addition, a student should be able to add text labels, etc. How do I create such a palette and use it in PoodLL?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: It would be a great thing. But PoodLL does not do that now, and I don't think it could be made to do so easily. There probably is something like that on the net. A quick search turned up this: http://webducate.net/products/dragster/ You might make activities in that (or something like it) and embed them in Moodle.
Comment 2: Thanks for the suggestion. That won't work because we plan to use Moodle for proctored exams (no internet access) and for some of the exams, the ability of students to draw circuits quickly is vital. Is it possible to do what I suggested without the snap points (if that is the complication)?
Comment 3: Its more than just the "snap" feature. To drag and drop predefined shapes onto the image would be possible, but would require custom coding. And it would be a like using a knife as a screwdriver. Rather than take the whiteboard in that direction, a separate Drag and Drop widget/plugin would be a better idea I feel. Do you think the OU drag and drop image or text question type would do the job for you: https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=qtype_ddimageortext
Comment 4: Thanks for the suggestion. That is a very interesting tool. I am afraid that that pre-supposes certain points on the canvas that need to be filled up. In a circuit drawing application (or a parts drawing application that a mechanical engineer might be interested in), that does not make any sense. The student is expected to start drawing from a blank slate, and it is interconnectivity of the parts, rather than the precise placement geometrically that matters. What would be the right forum for this? And if one does not exist, what would be the level of coding prowess needed for me to start writing a module (not that I have any time to spare, but still it would be helpful to know)?

Post title: Proctored Poodll for a Single quiz course?
Post description: We have created a dev site and plan to use Moodle and Poodll in a specific and limited way: to allow Users to choose a Course that is One Quiz, and we record their test-taking as a proctored system. If and when they pass, they get a grade VALUE that is in the range of 0 to 1000. We are using the latest versions, Moodle 2.6 etc, on a modern server (Rochen) Specifics, User Pathway/experience 1. The User sees a list of courses, renamed as “___ Tests”. Each Course consists of one Quiz; when completed they have completed the Course. 2. User chooses to take Quiz, then ideally they are auto-enrolled(? they are already registered and logged in, so can we do this?) . 3. They see preface screen to the test, showing them test-taking info and links, advisories about the test, etc. 4. They start the fifteen minute timed quiz. The video tapes them automatically and they see the recorder (themselves) on screen. A proctor will review it, to compare it to "face on file", and to prevent cheating in several ways (looking at notes, asking someone for answers, etc). 3. Those videos are then deleted, unless there is a controversy. The effort so far: Thanks in advance, and my apologies if we missed something obvious! Greg
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Greg, I replied to your email also. But I will just update here too so that we are all up to speed. It would be nice to know how you use PoodLL in the quiz. Is it a PoodLL Recording Question type? Or is it some other way? And what does "not working" or "not integrating" look or behave like? Justin
Comment 2: Justin, Can PoodLL be used to record   the whole session when a student takes a test(using webcam)? In addition, if the the course is setup as a single quiz. I would like the student to be recorded automatically when a student is taking a test - so that we know that the authorized student is taking the test and not some friend. Is this standard functionality for PoodLL ? Will the student get an error message if for some reason he/she does not have a webcam? Thanks. Yogesh
Comment 3: Yogesh There is no standard way to do this in PoodLL. It is possible, but probably not without custom coding. I have implemented a solution where each question was video recorded, ie not the whole test in one video, but one video per question. However that is not in the public domain , so I believe that I can't share it with you. Another approach would be to house the quiz in an iframe (via LTI ?) and do the video recording from outside the iframe. Then it would be a simple one video / one quiz scenario. But there would be coding involved. Justin
Comment 4: Thanks, Justin. Appreciate it.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Stripping Video from iOS uploads
Post description: Hey guys, Poodll is working great on my test server , and we're getting ready to deploy a few test rounds to replace our ageing cassette Language Lab. I have one concern/request. We are going to be using this primarily with mobile devices (though there are plans to also use the computer lab with it as well). Currently, mobile devices upload video to the system which is completely unnescessary for us. What I'm hoping for is a demux ability in poodll that I haven't seen before. Something that strips the video bitstream out of the file and leaves me with just the audio stored on the server. Is there a setting for this that I am missing, or is it currently not possible?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Nelson. Yes it does that provided you have FFMPEG set up. See here: http://poodll.com/documentation/1.0/11/audio-and-video-conversion/ If you just put the ffmpeg file in the /filter/poodll folder and check the checkbox as on the documentation file, that should be enough. Make sure the ffmpeg can create mp3 and permissions are executable. I have a raft of notes and docs on this, so let me know if you get into trouble
Comment 2: The impression I'm getting from this is it's converting (reencoding) the audio stream, which I would rather the system not do (It's not all that powerful). Or is it demuxing the streams and I'm just misunderstanding? As far as I'm concerned, the final audio format isn't important, so much as just not wasting all that space with the video file attached and not burn resources on a relatively slow processor which has been commandeered for the purpose.
Comment 3: It is set up to convert to mp3, so where the audio stream of the incoming file is not mp3, it will re-encode. With flv, you could just remove video and the remaining audio would play (as flv). I don't know how that would work with mov files though. There is the ability to specify encoding options for ffmpeg, there on the PoodLL filter settings page, but it does assume the end format will be mp3. In my own experience the conversion to mp3 is not a significant drag on the server, but it depends on how many conversions you have going on simultaneously. Related to this, I hope to implement background encoding sometime soon, so that the user doesn't have to wait for conversions to finish.

Post title: Installation of 'Online PoodLL submissions'-module fails in my Moodle 2.4.4 environment
Post description: I'm trying to install 'Poodll Assignment Submission module' using the ' git ' method. During Moodle plugin configuration phase I do get following error message: ---8<--- Debug info: Errors found in XMLDB file: Problem loading table assignsubmission_onlinepoodl, Some FIELDS previous/next values are incorrect Error code: ddlxmlfileerror Stack trace: line 349 of /lib/ddl/database_manager.php: ddl_exception thrown line 365 of /lib/ddl/database_manager.php: call to database_manager->load_xmldb_file() line 436 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to database_manager->install_from_xmldb_file() line 1544 of /lib/upgradelib.php: call to upgrade_plugins() line 349 of /admin/index.php: call to upgrade_noncore() ---8<--- Any ideas what could cause this error? My Moolde version is: Moodle 2.4.4 (Build: 20130513) MySQL : Client API library version     5.1.66 Client API header version     5.1.49 PHP: 5.3.3 Regards JP
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: That is because I used the Moodle XMLDB editor to make the install. xml which creates the database tables and fields for the plugin. In Moodle 2.5 the need for specifying previous and next  fields was removed. See here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=262188 So while I previously had previous/next values, the XMLDB editor removed them. I have put them back now, for all the people stuck on pre Moodle 2.5 versions. Just navigate to your [moodle]/mod/assign/submission/onlinepoodll directory, and do a git  pull And you should get the fixes. Post back if you run into problems.
Comment 2: Thanks a lot! After pulling your latest changes everything worked fine. Regards JP

Post title: PoodLL Cheat Sheet
Post description: Here is a cheat sheet of most (not all) of the PoodLL filter string types. I have been meaning to do this for *years* but rashly promised to do it today to a webinar. So it is done. Not all the options for each type are listed, but the main ones are. The URL is here: http://www.cheatography.com/justinhunt/cheat-sheets/poodll-filter/ The PDF download is attached to this forum post, but in the future you should get the latest from the url above. For those who don't know what this is all about, Poodll has a whole bunch of widgets that can be inserted into Moodle. eg a stopwatch. You do that by inserting a crafty little string that looks like this: {POODLL:type=stopwatch} which turns into stopwatch when you view the activity. The cheat sheet contains information about those crafty filter strings. You can play around, and see them, over at http://demo.poodll.com **NB DON'T COPY AND PASTE THE FILTER STRINGS** The encoding of the text on the PDF and cheatsheet website is wrong. Even without that, invisible html characters often sneak in and break things. Just type the strings out longhand. Enjoy *edited 19/06/2014 added warning about copy/paste and file encoding*

Forum Post: 
Post title: Poodll plugin not working on MAC
Post description: I have tested http://demo.poodll.com/ on MAC. The recording level indicator does not respond. It shows that a file has been created but not getting uploaded. The uploading process goes on and on, never stops. Please reply with a solution or an alternate of this. Waiting for a quick and positive reply.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Sudeep Sorry for the slow reply. What browser are you using? And which recorder are you using? How long are your recordings? There are many things that can go wrong with recording. Most of them are at the browser end of things. Did you try rebooting and using a different browser? Google Chrome has a permissions dialog that is very hard to see. It pops up when you first try to use your webcam/mike on a site. It appears just beneath the address bar in the browser. Almost everyone misses it, even I forget about it. And of course there is the standard flash permissions dialog. If permission is not granted to the camera/mic then the recording will usually fail in the way you describe. Also if Skype or another application is trying to use the webcamera, it can be unavailable for the browser. Sometimes it happens that the other app doesn't release it. Even when the other app is closed down the camera is unavailable. I wonder in these cases if there is a problem with the driver software. I sometimes get this on my mac. Anyway, rebooting and trying a different browser are good steps to take. Finally depending on the recorder you are using, try not selecting "mp3" or "mp4" on the recorder. Sometimes the conversion process is failing because the server is too busy, or the recording too long, to respond before the browser gives up waiting. Justin

Post title: PoodLL and Windows XP
Post description: Hello We are running Moodle 2.5.1+ (Build: 20130712) Version 2013051401.02 and have had PoodLL working successfully since last summer.  This semester I have a student using Windows XP who reports she is able to record using PoodLL but is unable to upload the PoodLL file.  She is following the directions provided and can get to step 6 but is unable to see/click the Next button to proceed to step 7.  This is the only student in a class of 18 to report a problem and I have been unable to duplicate it. Has anyone encountered a similar issue and if so, were you able to resolve it? Thank you, Susan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Tracked down a computer running XP and absolutely no issues with recording using PoodLL using either Firefox or Internet Explorer; I also received confirmation from the developer of PoodLL that it is XP compatible so I am starting to think, this may be a user issue and relate to the local computer configuration.  If anyone can point me in another direction, I would be wide open to ideas...
Comment 2: I run a classroom full of XP based computers. With all the add-ons we use, including PoodLL, the only time one of them has had a problem like this was when we forgot to make sure the browser add-ons were enabled after various updates. Students sometimes miss the little pop-up warnings or turn them off without bothering to read them.

Post title: Poodll
Post description: I asked my Moodle admin to install the Poodll plugin we are using Moodle 2.5.1+ (Build: 20130712) He replied "The poodll plugin for audio requires a higher version of moodle" But when I looked I thought it was ok.  Can you tell me if any of the versions would work for our 2.5.1 version? This really would be an exciting plugin to offer our users! Thanks for your time! Ann
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: HI Ann PoodLL works for anything from Moodle 2.1 up. ( Though nobody should really be that far back. ) So your Moodle admin might be thinking of something else, or might have misread something. Please try again. Justin
Comment 2: Hi Justin, My Moodle admin  was looking at this site for downloads http://poodll.com/downloads-for-poodll-2-3/ We have Moodle 2.5.1+ (Build: 20130712) I see this on the Moodle.org website https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=13 shouldn't this be the place for downloading? Would you recommend to download all of the Poodll plugins? Thanks! Ann
Comment 3: Hi Ann, Yes, I would recommend downloading and using all of the PoodLL plugins. The only one I think about being optional is the PoodLL Online (assignment_poodllonline) as it is for the old Assignment 2.2 type, which I no longer use. Your first link you have listed above downloads directly from Justin's site and if you get the Kaboodle, it will include all you need to get going.The second link is also ok, just have to download the different parts, one at a time. The main add-on of the bunch that all the other parts depend on is the filter. Their installation depends on the filter being installed, too. If your site folder permissions are set right and your site is registered with Moodle, an admin can actually do all the installs right in Moodle 2.5.x, by going to Administration > Site Administration > Plugins > Install add-ons then click on Install add-ons from the Moodle plugins directory. AL
Comment 4: Hi Ann, Just like Al said really. If you have a clear idea of where you want to use it, then you could just download the modules you need. Most people probably don't use the 2.2 assignment type anymore or the database activity field(though you can do fun stuff with it) . So if you install piecemeal from Moodle.org, you might leave those off. The one mod you must have is the PoodLL filter. Everything else uses stuff from there. Stuff generally goes up on poodll.com earlier than on Moodle.org. But at the moment everything is up to date everywhere. Just to confuse things, there is a new mod, PoodLL Anywhere. It adds recording icons to the TinyMCE editor. If you use that you probably don't need the PoodLL repository anymore either. PoodLL Anywhere can be downloaded from the page you referenced, but it is not in the Kaboodle bundle or available from Moodle.org yet. Hmm, lets summarize this a bit PoodLL Add-on On PoodLL.com In Kaboodle On Moodle.org Notes PoodLL Filter Yes Yes Yes PoodLL Question Type Yes Yes Yes PoodLL Repository Yes Yes Yes PoodLL Assignment Submission Yes Yes Yes for new Moodle assignment (avail. from Moodle 2.3) PoodLL Assignment Feedback Yes Yes Yes for new Moodle assignment (avail. from Moodle 2.3) PoodLL Assignment Type Yes Yes Yes for old Moodle assignment PoodLL Anywhere Yes No No adds PoodLL icons to TinyMCE HTML area PoodLL Database Activity Field Yes Yes Yes
Comment 5: Thanks Justin! You are awesome! I am excited and can't wait to have this installed! Ann
Comment 6: Hey Justin, Thanks for the info about the new PoodLL Anywhere plugin for the TinyMCE Editor. Makes an already great set of plugins even better and more versatile. I was on your site just a day or two before you released it, so only just now found out about it. Thanks to Birmingham City University for getting you to develop it. Works great even on the current development version of Moodle 2.7. AL
Comment 7: Sure beats clicking through to the repositories all the time ... Justin
Comment 8: I have used Poodll on 2.3 and 2.5 with no problems at all - in fact its currently live on my 2.5 site now (It's an excellent set of plugins!)
Comment 9: I have used Poodll on 2.3;  2.4; 2.5 and 2.6, the best and the most powerful plugs! We love it.
Comment 10: Thanks everyone!  I am passing on the information!  I appreciate all your help!

Forum Post: Post title: Installing poodll Post description: New user here with  a shiny 2.6 version. Keen to have students record their own voices so downloaded Poodll Kabodle. Noticed the version was only up to 2,5 but went ahead anyway because I am that sort of guy. Uploaded the zip to my site, extracted, copied directories. Noticed there as no overwrite messages as suggested in the Poodll docs  but Moodle upgraded my database and declared the whole thing a success, Added an assignment and sure enough there is a Poodl voice recorder and whiteboard option and I ticked the mp3 submission. The assignment does not show the recorder widget though- what have I missed? The assignment does not have any sort of recording feature available. I checked the docs and it mentioned configuring Modules->Filters->Manage Filters under site admin. I can't locate this. Is it my version or just me lost in the menus? Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Sounds like very out of date docs... Site administration > Plugins > Filters > Manage Filters ...however, I have never seen Poodl (sp?) so that may be nothing to do with your issue. Comment 2: Hi James, Yes, the PoodLL Filter has to be enabled for any of the other parts of PoodLL to work. It is located at Site Administration >  Plugins > Filters > Manage Filters. The PoodLL Filter Active should be set to On. The Apply to should be set to either Content or Content and Headings. You should also have it higher in the list than the Multimedia plugins filter, or you may see two players in some locations instead of just the PoodLL player. HTH , AL Comment 3: Hi James Just like Al and Howard said, the filter settings are at: Site Administration >  Plugins > Filters > Manage Filters And PoodLL in particular (once enabled) at Site Administration >  Plugins > Filters > PoodLL Filter It should actually work without the PoodLL filter being enabled , though that is not the usual setup. There are two main possibilities for this situation that are really just about learning how to use the Moodel assignment. ( I am assuming this is the new Moodle assignment (new as of Moodle 2.3). If you didn't know that there was an older version of the Moodle assignment, then you are probably ok. Since it should default to the new one.) i) did you configure PoodLL recording for the assignment submission? Or the assignment feedback? The assignment submission is what the student will do. The assignment feedback is how you respond to them. ii) Are you testing this by logging in as a student? By default a non student can't actually even do the assignment. So you have to be a student, then you will see a button saying "add submission" and it all starts from there. Justin Comment 4: Woohoo! I have created a student recording. Thanks everyone for their time and your suggestions ( filters, add a submission) were just what I needed.  Starting to feel like I can achieve something. Comment 5: Step forward, step back. I can see Poodll depends on the student's device to do the recording and the recording widget in the assignment shows up fine on my brand new laptop. However trying to record using  a 2.2 Android Tablet told me Android 4 was necessary. I think many of my students usually access the net through Android phones rather than from computers and the recording looks well suited to accessing using Android. The recording app looks great but where to from here? I might try a poll of students to see how many use the same sort of outdated technology as me. Comment 6: Yes, prior to Android 4 and iOS 6, file upload was not possible using the Mobile Safari and the android default browser. PoodLL handles recordings from mobile devices using the file upload dialog, because it is possible to record at least video, and in most Android cases audio also, directly from there. Anyway I put the version check there, because it was not clear to students on older OS why it was not working. Sorry about the limit, but it is out of our hands really. Comment 7: I understand - there must be hundreds of variations of hardware/browser and version numbers for users and an impossibility to support every variation. It does seem though to limit the usefulness of the audio recording to a situation where the user all use the same setup, as in a language lab, as opposed to using their own devices. Comment 8: Had a look today at setup for students in language labs, shared computers and think I spoke too soon - students should be able to access a machine which can submit a recording through Poodll. A standard recording, a common format and time limits are too good to ignore. Comment 9: Wonderful that sounds good. It is also nice to have them all in one room when you first do it, so that you can walk them through it. eg When the flash permissions dialog popups ... You can tell them what to do. If they record audio regularly the nervousness and pressure fade away, but the first few times it helps to take it slowly. So I might ask them to practice their speech/introduction a few times with different partners before they record. Also if you make the thing that they record basically a no brainer, eg say some tongue twisters, sing a nursery rhyme, or read a dialog from the book. That lowers the bar too. You will possibly run into technical quicksands the first time you do it. eg The browsers are too old, or half the microphones are broken . So it pays to do the activity yourself on the student machines first, so you know what will happen for them. Not doing this still catches me out sometimes. And making the first activity obviously not important ( some tongue twisters etc) means you won't get students too frustrated if things don't go right. Comment 10: Hi, similar follow-up question.  Brand new Moodle 2.6+ install, just installed Poodll for the first time over the weekend. Awsome plugin. Comment 11: HI Mike So  the students assignment submission for video works, but the teachers feedback doesn't. And that you think it might be the flash permissions for the webcam/microphone. I have not heard of that specific problem, but there are a few things you might check. Does it work from a different browser? And if you are using Chrome, did you see the little popup permissions dialog that Chrome requires for webcam access?  If you didn't see it, and it is very easy to miss, that might be the problem. It shows just below the address bar of your browser. Also is the little connection lamp on the lower left of the recorder green? If not you won't be able to record until a connection to the recording server is made. Do other PoodLL feedback types work, eg mp3 recording or whiteboard? I made a lot of changes "under the hood" recently. So it is possible I missed something in the PoodLL Feedback mod, so please let me know how you get on. Comment 14: Mike I was able to login and leave a  video as feedback. Even though  I was behind a firewall and on a poor connection, which affects the recording quality. But I am in Japan and so a lot closer to the Red5 server than you. Sooo, it might just be a problem with your connection to the red5 server. That would not explain why you can record as a student but not as a teacher though. If you try lowering the capture size of the video from 480x360 to something lower. Does that make a difference? Post title: Poodll repositories
Post description: Hi, I am not sure if this is the right place to post this or not. If not, please let me know. I would like to give faculty the ability to give and receive audio for feedback and assignment from within Moodle. We are running 2.5.2 (and plan to upgrade to 2.5.2 in a few weeks). Has anyone used any of these: https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=13 I am particularly interested in these for recording audio: https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=repository_poodll https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=assignsubmission_onlinepoodll https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=qtype_poodllrecording Does anyone have any experience with these? Is there another you would recommend over these? Thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I have them on my system in work, and although they are not in widespread use yet (we upgraded to 2.5 ready for this term which started this week and Poodll was added as part of that upgrade) they work very well in all the testing I have done with them and look very easy to use. Richard
Comment 2: All PoodLL plugins are working very well in my Moodle2.4 and 2.5. The PoodLL should be included into the core. It will bring up Moodle to a super multimedia LMS. Go PoodLL!
